entities: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE)
summary:
The Security Council, recalling its previous resolutions on the conflicts in the former Yugoslavia, reaffirms its commitment to a political settlement of the conflicts, preserving the sovereignty and territorial integrity of all States within their internationally recognized borders. The Council emphasizes its support for the High Representative’s continued role in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the implementation of the General Framework Agreement for Peace (Peace Agreement). 

It underlines the importance of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s progress towards Euro-Atlantic integration and its transition to a functional, reform-oriented, modern, and democratic European country. The Council welcomes the European Union’s increased engagement in Bosnia and Herzegovina and NATO’s continued presence.

The Council reiterates its calls on the authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina to implement their undertakings, as confirmed by the Peace Implementation Council Steering Board declaration of 27 February 2008. It notes the signing of the Stabilization and Association Agreement (SAA) as a fundamental step forward in the relationship between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the European Union.

The Council emphasizes its appreciation for the contributions of the High Representative, EUFOR, NATO, OSCE, EU, and other international organizations and agencies. It recognizes that full implementation of the Peace Agreement is not yet complete, while paying tribute to the achievements of the authorities and the international community over the past thirteen years.

The Council determines to promote the peaceful resolution of conflicts in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations and welcomes efforts to sensitize peacekeeping personnel in the prevention and control of HIV/AIDS and other communicable diseases.
Here is a summarized version of the Security Council document:

The Security Council:

Reaffirms its support for the Peace Agreement and the Dayton Paris Agreement, and calls on parties to comply with their obligations.

Notes with satisfaction an agreement between leaders of three main parties in Bosnia and Herzegovina, reached on 8 November 2008.

Determines that the situation in the region continues to constitute a threat to international peace and security.

Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter:

1. Reaffirms support for the Peace Agreement and calls on parties to comply with their obligations.
